title: How to Get Help with Utility Bills: LIHEAP and Other Resources
summary: When utility bills become overwhelming, federal and local programs like LIHEAP can offer energy assistance to low-income households. Learn how to apply, whatâ€™s covered, and where to find help.

body.raw:
## Introduction If youâ€™re struggling to keep the lights on or the heat running, youâ€™re not alone. High energy bills can hit low-income families the hardest â€” especially in the summer or winter months. Fortunately, **LIHEAP** and other programs exist to help you cover the cost of electricity, gas, and other utilities. *** ## What Is LIHEAP? The **Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program (LIHEAP)** is a federally funded initiative that helps households with: - **Heating and cooling bills** - **Crisis assistance** during shutoff notices - **Weatherization improvements** The program is administered at the **state and local level**, and eligibility depends on your household size and income. ## Who Qualifies for LIHEAP? Each state sets its own income limits, but you generally qualify if your income is at or below **150% of the federal poverty level**. Other qualifying factors may include: 1. Receiving benefits like SNAP, SSI, or TANF 2. Being a senior, disabled, or having a young child in the home 3. Having a shutoff notice or no heating/cooling Some states also offer priority assistance for emergencies, seniors, or families with children. ## How to Apply for Utility Assistance Applying for LIHEAP or similar programs is usually straightforward: 1. **Find your stateâ€™s LIHEAP office** or benefits website 2. **Gather documentation** like ID, income verification, and utility bills 3. **Submit an application online or in person** 4. **Follow up** if you donâ€™t hear back in a week or two In many cases, funds are paid directly to the utility company on your behalf. If you're also behind on rent, check [Emergency Rental Assistance](./emergency-rental-assistance-what-it-is-and-how-to-apply-before-it-s-gone) for support. ## Other Utility Help Programs - **Weatherization Assistance Program (WAP)**: Helps improve energy efficiency - **Local utility company hardship funds**: Many power/gas companies offer their own emergency aid - **Nonprofits like the Salvation Army or 211.org** often provide energy assistance or referrals > ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** Even if you think you donâ€™t qualify, apply anyway â€” some states offer tiered benefits, and crisis situations can override income thresholds. *** ###### References
